sen.j: 小川月神社（おがわつきじんじゃ）は、京都府亀岡市馬路町に鎮座する神社。
sen.e: Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine is located in Umaji-cho, Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine is located in Umaji-cho, Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine is located in Umaji-cho, Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 名神大社とされ、近代社格制度は村社。
sen.e: This shrine was classified as Myojin-taisha (a shrine dedicated to Myojin (a gracious deity)), and then categorized as Sonsha (a village shrine) in Kindai shakaku seido (Modern shrine ranking system).

This shrine was classified as a Myojin-taisha (a shrine dedicated to a Myojin, a gracious deity), and then categorized as a Sonsha (a village shrine) in the Kindai shakaku seido (modern shrine ranking system).
sen.cmt: I assume "gracious deity" is an appropriate explanation of Myojin, but I have been unable to confirm it.
sen.e: This shrine was classified as a Myojin-taisha (a shrine dedicated to a Myojin, a gracious deity), and then categorized as a Sonsha (a village shrine) in the Kindai shakaku seido (modern shrine ranking system).

sen.j: 当神社は大堰川の左岸（東側）に鎮座している。
sen.e: This shrine is located on the left (east) side of the Oi-gawa River.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割しました）
sen.e: This shrine is located on the left (east) side of the Oi-gawa River.
This shrine is located on the left (east) side of the Oi-gawa River.

sen.j: 大堰川を挟んだ西方、千代川町に小川という字名があり、『和名抄』に見える「桑田郡小川郷」の遺称地であるとされている。
sen.e: A region on the west side of the river in Chiyokawa-cho is called Ogawa, which is believed to be where "Ogawa-go village, Kuwata-gun County" was located according to "Wamyo-sho (a dictionary compiled in the Heian period)".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割しました）
sen.e: A region on the west side of the river in Chiyokawa-cho is called Ogawa, and this is believed to be where "Ogawa-go village, Kuwata-gun County" mentioned in the "Wamyo-sho" (a dictionary compiled in the Heian period) was located.

A region on the west side of the river in Chiyokawa-cho is called Ogawa, and this is believed to be where 'Ogawa-go village, Kuwata-gun County' mentioned in the "Wamyo-sho" (a dictionary compiled in the Heian period) was located.

sen.j: そのため、かつての大堰川は当神社の東を流れ、当神社一帯も小川郷に含まれており、郷名を冠する神社名となったと見られている。
sen.e: It is believed that the shrine name includes the village name because the Oi-gawa River once run in the east of this shrine, and the area around the shrine belonged to the Ogawa-go village.
It is believed that the shrine name includes the village name because the Oi-gawa River once ran to the east of the shrine, and the area around the shrine belonged to the Ogawa-go village.
It is believed that the shrine name includes the village name because the Oi-gawa River once ran to the east of the shrine, and the area around the shrine belonged to the Ogawa-go village.

sen.j: 明治以前には「月読（神）社」を称し、現在でも「つきよみさん」と呼ばれて親しまれている。
sen.e: Before the Meiji period, it was called "Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine", and it still gains popularity with the nickname of "Tsukiyomi-san" today.
Before the Meiji period, it was called "Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine," and the nickname of "Tsukiyomi-san" is still popular today.
Before the Meiji period, it was called 'Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine,' and the nickname of 'Tsukiyomi-san' is still popular today.

sen.j: 月読命
sen.e: Tsukuyomi no mikoto
Tsukuyomi no mikoto
Tsukuyomi no mikoto

sen.j: 大堰川沿いには他にも松尾神社があるので、下流の松尾大社の摂社月読神社 (京都市)との関係が指摘されている。
sen.e: Another shrine called Matsuo-jinja, which is located along the Oi-gawa River, is believed to have had a relationship with the Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine, a Sessha (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)) of the Matsuo-taisha Shrine (in Kyoto City), which is located in the lower reach of the river.

Another shrine called Matsuo-jinja, which is located along the Oi-gawa River, is believed to have had a relationship with the Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine, a Sessha (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity closely related to that of the main shrine)) of the Matsuo-taisha Shrine (in Kyoto City), which is located in the lower reach of the river.

Another shrine called Matsuo-jinja, which is located along the Oi-gawa River, is believed to have had a relationship with the Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine, a Sessha (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity closely related to that of the main shrine)) of the Matsuo-taisha Shrine (in Kyoto City), which is located in the lower reach of the river.

sen.j: 上述松尾大社との関係から、大堰川を遡る形で秦氏による開発が進み、それにともなって創祀されたと考えられている。
sen.e: Taking into consideration the relationship with the above-mentioned Matsuo-taisha Shrine, this shrine is believed to have been founded in the course of the area development in the upstream direction by the Hata clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割）
sen.e: Taking into consideration the relationship with the above-mentioned Matsuo-taisha Shrine, this shrine is believed to have been founded in the course of the area development in the upstream direction by the Hata clan.

Taking into consideration the relationship with the above-mentioned Matsuo-taisha Shrine, this shrine is believed to have been founded in the course of the area development in the upstream direction by the Hata clan.

sen.j: しかし、氏子総代保管の「丹波国桑田郡小川月神社之事」という年不明の文書に、伊勢神宮が丹後国与謝郡に遷座した時の末社であるとも、丹波国に鎮座していた時の末社であるともし、「神代よりの旧地なり」と記している。
sen.e: According to "Record of Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine in Kuwata-gun, Tanba Province", which was written in an unknown year and stored by the representative of shrine parishioners, this shrine is said to have been a Massha (small shrine belonging to the main shrine) when the Ise-jingu Shrine was transferred to Yosa County, Tango Province, or a Massha when it was enshrined in Tanba Province, and it is also described as "remains since the mythological age".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割、文頭に「しかし」を追加）
sen.e: According to "Record of the Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine in Kuwata-gun, Tanba Province," which was written in an unknown year and stored by the representatives of shrine parishioners, this shrine is said to have been a Massha (small shrine belonging to the main shrine) when the Ise-jingu Shrine was transferred to Yosa County, Tango Province, or a Massha when it was enshrined in Tanba Province, and it is also described as "remaining from the mythological age."

According to 'Record of the Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine in Kuwata County, Tanba Province,' which was written in an unknown year and stored by the representatives of shrine parishioners, this shrine is said to have been a Massha (small shrine belonging to the main shrine) when the Ise-jingu Shrine was transferred to Yosa County, Tango Province, or a Massha when it was enshrined in Tanba Province, and it is also described as 'remaining from the mythological age.'

sen.j: また、出雲神社（現亀岡市千歳町の出雲大神宮）の鎮座よりも古く、同神社と同等の神社で桑田郡の「第二之大社也」とも記す。
sen.e: The foundation was earlier than that of the Izumo-jinja Shrine (present-day Izumo Daijingu Shrine in Chitose-cho, Kameoka City), and as this shrine was at the same level as the Izumo-jinja Shrine, it was also called "the second Taisha" of Kuwata-gun Country.

Its foundation was earlier than that of the Izumo-jinja Shrine (present-day Izumo Daijingu Shrine in Chitose-cho, Kameoka City), and as this shrine was at the same level as the Izumo-jinja Shrine, it was also called "the second Taisha" of Kuwata-gun Country.

Its foundation was earlier than that of the Izumo-jinja Shrine (present-day Izumo Daijingu Shrine in Chitose-cho, Kameoka City), and as this shrine was at the same level as the Izumo-jinja Shrine, it was also called 'the second Taisha' of Kuwata-gun Country.

sen.j: 『神社明細帳』によれば、応仁（1467-69年）に大堰川の洪水によって社地を流失し、以後小祠として祀られるようになったとある。
sen.e: According to "Jinja Meisaicho (Official records of Shinto shrines)", the shrine was washed away by the Oi-gawa River flood during the Onin period (1467 to1469), and since then it has been worshipped as Shoshi (a small shrine).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割しました）
sen.e: According to "Jinja Meisaicho (Official records of Shinto shrines)," the shrine was washed away by the Oi-gawa River flood during the Onin period (1467 to1469), and since then it has been worshiped as Shoshi (a small shrine).

According to "Jinja Meisaicho" (Official records of Shinto shrines), the shrine was washed away by the Oi-gawa River flood during the Onin period (1467 to1469), and since then it has been worshiped as Shoshi (a small shrine).

sen.j: 前掲文書にも応永（1394-1428年）の洪水を記し、或いは兵乱によって廃弊して以後「境内狭小にして祭祀等無之」とも記す。
sen.e: In the above-mentioned record, it is said that the flood occurred during the Onin period (1394 to 1428), and that "no religious services are held because the shrine site is too small" after the place was ruined during the flood or battles.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割しました）
sen.e: In the above-mentioned record, it is said that the flood occurred during the Onin period (1394 to 1428), and that "no religious services are held because the shrine site is too small" after the place was ruined during floods or battles.

In the above-mentioned record, it is said that the flood occurred during the Onin period (1394 to 1428), and that "no religious services are held because the shrine site is too small" after the place was ruined during floods or battles.

sen.j: いずれにせよ、大堰川の流路変更などで被災、退転したと考えられている。
sen.e: In either case, it seems that the shrine was damaged due to the flow path change of the Oi-gawa River, etc. and was moved to the other place.
In either case, it seems that the shrine was damaged due to the flow path change of the Oi-gawa River, etc. and was moved to another place.
In either case, it seems that the shrine was damaged due to the flow path change of the Oi-gawa River, etc. and was moved to another place.

sen.j: なお、大堰川対岸の千代川町小川にも同じく月読命を祀る月読神社が存在する。
sen.e: In Ogawa of Chiyoda-cho on the opposite side of the Oi-gawa River, there is another shrine called Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine, which also enshrines the Tsukiyomi no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割しました）
sen.e: In Ogawa of Chiyoda-cho on the opposite side of the Oi-gawa River, there is another shrine called Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine, which also enshrines the Tsukiyomi no Mikoto.
In Ogawa of Chiyoda-cho on the opposite side of the Oi-gawa River, there is another shrine called Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine, which also enshrines the Tsukiyomi no Mikoto.

sen.j: これは大堰川の流路変更によって当神社と隔てられた人々が新しく氏神として当神社から勧請したものであると見られている。
sen.e: It is believed that this shrine was build for enshrining the divided deity as Ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) by the people who were separated from the Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine area due to the change of the Oi-gawa River's flow path.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割しました）
sen.e: It is believed that this shrine was built for enshrining the divided deity as Ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) by the people who were separated from the Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine area due to the change of the Oi-gawa River's flow path.

It is believed that this shrine was built for enshrining the divided deity as Ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) by the people who were separated from the Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine area due to the change of the Oi-gawa River's flow path.

sen.j: 明治になって村社とされたが、明治10年（1877年）に式内名神大社に比定され、同年6月の京都府名義の確認書に「月読社 延喜式内小川月神社ニ相違無之候」とある。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, this shrine was categorized as Sonsha, and then identified as Shikinai Myojin-taisha in 1877, as the confirmation written under the name of Kyoto Prefecture in June 1877 says that "Tsukiyomi-sha is definitely the Engishikinaisha Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine".

In the Meiji period, this shrine was categorized as Sonsha, and then identified as Shikinai Myojin-taisha in 1877, as the confirmation written under the name of Kyoto Prefecture in June 1877 says that "Tsukiyomi-sha is definitely the Engishikinaisha Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine."

In the Meiji period, this shrine was categorized as Sonsha, and then identified as Shikinai Myojin-taisha in 1877, as the confirmation written under the name of Kyoto Prefecture in June 1877 says that 'Tsukiyomi-sha is definitely the Engishikinaisha Ogawatsuki-jinja Shrine.'

sen.j: 当神社が確かに式内社であれば、貞観 (日本)元年（859年）正月27日に従五位下から従五位上に昇叙された記録が残る（『日本三代実録』）。
sen.e: If this shrine is certainly Shikinai-sha (a shrine listed in Engishiki laws), there is a record that this shrine was promoted from Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) to Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) on January 27, 859 ("Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts)).

If this shrine is certainly Shikinai-sha (a shrine listed in Engishiki laws), there is a record that this shrine was promoted from Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) to Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) on January 27, 859 ("Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts)).

If this shrine is certainly Shikinai-sha (a shrine listed in Engishiki laws), there is a record that this shrine was promoted from Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) to Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) on March 9, 859 ("Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts)).

sen.j: 10月16日の例祭に、1年間に誕生した子供全員の祈祷をする慣例があり、由緒は不明ながらも地域全体で子供たちの無事な成長を願うものである。
sen.e: In Reisai (regular festival) on October 16, the whole community prays for all the children who were born within one year so that they grow up well, although the origin is not sure.
In Reisai (regular festival) on October 16, the whole community prays for all the children who were born within the year so that they grow up well, although the origin is not certain.
In Reisai (regular festival) on October 16, the whole community prays for all the children who were born within the year so that they grow up well, although the origin is not certain.

sen.j: 前掲氏子総代文書に「貞村守護してより春秋ニ不絶祭祀す」とある。
sen.e: It is described in the above-mentioned record stored by the representative of parishioners that "since Sadamura started serving, the ritual has been handed down for years".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割）
sen.e: It is described in the above-mentioned record stored by the representatives of parishioners that "since Sadamura started serving, the ritual has been handed down for years."
It is described in the above-mentioned record stored by the representatives of parishioners that 'since Sadamura started serving, the ritual has been handed down for years.'

sen.j: 社伝によれば、北条時頼が廻国の途中に参拝し、家臣の人見次郎貞村という者に神社の守護を命じ、長らく人見家が30代にわたって奉仕してきたが、その後氏子総代が維持経営にあたるようになったという（境内案内看板より）。
sen.e: According to the record of the shrine, when Tokiyori HOJO visited this shrine on the way, he told one of his servants, named Jiro Sadamura HITOMI, to guard the shrine, thereafter the HITOMI Family served for 30 generations and then the representative of the shrine parishioners has succeeded the management and maintenance role (according to the signboard in the shrine's ground).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割）
sen.e: According to the record of the shrine, when Tokiyori HOJO visited this shrine on the way, he told one of his servants, named Jiro Sadamura HITOMI, to guard the shrine, thereafter the HITOMI Family served for 30 generations and then the representatives of the shrine parishioners have succeeded the management and maintenance role (according to the signboard on the shrine's grounds).

According to the record of the shrine, when Tokiyori HOJO visited this shrine on the way, he told one of his servants, named Jiro Sadamura HITOMI, to guard the shrine, thereafter the Hitomi family served for 30 generations and then the representatives of the shrine parishioners have succeeded the management and maintenance role (according to the signboard on the shrine's grounds).

sen.j: 覆屋内の流造の本殿と、方1間妻入瓦葺の拝殿とのみからなり、拝殿は年不明ながら出雲大神宮より遷されたものであると伝える。
sen.e: This shrine consists of the main shrine in the Nagare-zukuri style (flow style), which is enclosed with Oiya (covering building), and the front shrine made of one square room with the Tsumairi (entrance on the gable end) and thatched roof, which has reportedly been transferred from the Izumo Daijingu Shrine in an unknown year.

This shrine consists of the main shrine in the Nagare-zukuri style (flow style), which is enclosed with Oiya (building covering), and the front shrine is made of one square room with the Tsumairi (entrance on the gable end) and thatched roof, which has reportedly been transferred from the Izumo Daijingu Shrine in an unknown year.

This shrine consists of the main shrine in the Nagare-zukuri style (flow style), which is enclosed with Oiya (building covering), and the front shrine is made of one square room with the Tsumairi (entrance on the gable end) and thatched roof, which has reportedly been transferred from the Izumo Daijingu Shrine in an unknown year.
